subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit bug for XML testing?
msgSnippet: ... I find that code exhibiting the following qualities is easiest to test: - High cohesion - Low coupling - No duplication Not coincidentally, test-first
messageBody:
philipborlin@... wrote:

> Another thing that would be helpful is some best practices on how to write
> code that will be easy to test.
>

I find that code exhibiting the following qualities is easiest to test:

- High cohesion
- Low coupling
- No duplication

Not coincidentally, test-first development encourages these qualities. In order to
write the code, you have to figure out how to test it. To test it easily, you want the
code to be cohesive, yet not be dependent on too many other things. I find myself
favoring composition over inheritance, for example, so I can use mock objects to test
without breaking encapsulation. The design grows as a loose collaboration of simple,
yet responsible, objects.

Mike

--
Mike Clark
